Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown line profile of avalanche on E-SE aspect of Reynolds shoulder, about 3 feet deep and 200 feet wide. Depth hoar deep in the snowpack is extremely weak, can easily shove your arm into it. I did not have time to do any stability tests but avalanche activity was quite widespread on this layer.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, widespread; Cracking;
Collapsing, widespread; Cracking; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes;
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Ski tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Snowpack is poor and not to be trusted. Very weak basal snow (including true cupped depth hoar) was the failure point for two very different ECT's. One failed on isolation at the ground, causing the entire snowpack to tumble down on top of us. A second test resulted in ECTX, however an extra hard hit on 32 failed on the ground as well with similar dramatic results. I suspect more isloated tests (CT, etc.) would have had results on upper layers.
Our takeaway is that the likelihood of trigger is going down, however the destructive potential is still very high.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Wind loaded area lee of large plateau. ~5m above crown of 6 day old avalanche. Investigating SH. AG, CS.
Pigtail Snow Study Plot

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Ski tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Very weak basal snow was the failure point for two very different ECT's. One failed upon isolation at the ground (ECTPV), causing the entire snowpack to tumble down on top of us. Suspecting this as an outlier potentially caused by practitioner error, a second ECT was performed. Despite a score of ECTX, an extra hard hit on 32 caused the snowpack to fail on the ground with similar dramatic results.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Collapsing, widespread;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Noticed tons of collapsing and whumpfing out on our tour today. Our CT2 & ECTP12 showed that as well. We didnt see much wind loading (although the winds were heinous yesterday) mostly because there had been enough snowfall in todays calm winds to cover anything, and were we’re traveling through trees with some open patches.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Primary layer of concern was small facets under wind-drifted snow above pencil hard crust. Second layer was dry facets below the pencil hard crust. It will take a lot of weight to break through this crust and in this location I would imagine that the old/new snow interface and density changes would be the first layer to break in the newest snow and the potential for stepping down may exist, but it would be a lot of weight to break through this pencil hard crust. GCS 3

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Collapsing, widespread; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; Ski tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown profile on lower skier's left of SZ. Average crown depth 60-70cm, Maximum 80cm. SS-ASu-R3-D2-O. Average SZ Angle ~38 degrees. High angle track with MANY trees along its entirety. Snow was entrained from the track to the JAN 4 layer most of the track. Cracks propagated far into lower angle terrain to skiers left at 7700'. Calculated Runout Angle 31 deg. Not much tree damage - this path is a frequent runner. Flow height up to 2.5 meters above bed surface. Patient Location: 7370' 43.53311,-111.05651 Toe: 7230' 43.53292,-111.05556

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 30" of low density snow over the past week on top of a weak, faceted snowpack approximately 20" deep. The recent snow has finally consolidated into a 4f slab. Strong SW-NW winds have alternatively stripped and loaded a variety of aspects near treeline and above.
Minor wind loading, some compaction at surface (10cm low density) unconsolidated powder below.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Incredibly weak with just fluff on top - fair stability in sheltered areas like this with minimal water weight in the new snow and no slab. Higher elevations have more of a slab from today's winds. We have found buried surf hoar in other places as well, but it doesn't really matter. The facets are so weak and very widespread.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug adjacent to flank of fresh D2 avalanche. Structure at crown different - slab composed of sluff debris. Another fresh D2 soft slab a few hundred yards north - likely storm + recent snow. When breaking trail, recent snow felt upside down, though very low density for both layers.
Wind gusting to light from the west. Dug with EB.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Började snöa och blåsa under arbetet i testgropen. Inget snödrev. Mycket begränsad sikt vid TL och ingen sikt upp mot ALP. ECTP22 i bottenfacetter.
Glades treeline
At Kasiks High profile site

User.name: Avalanche Observer
User.affil: BC Ministry of Transportation NW Avalanche Program

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This is a baseline snow profile done adjacent to our Basecamp Wx plot location. This is the summary of 3 pits dug over a 20mx20m area.

A surprise 5"-7" of low density fluff came in last night ahead of a much anticipated, more powerful storm forecasted for tonight through tomorrow. 12"-15" at around 1.0" SWE is anticipated. Snowpack has been deteriorating for weeks. This is the first pit I've dug on a northerly aspect that had mid-pack supportability.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Small wind affected rolls at TL

Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Northern side of top part of the 5.1 slope in treeline. The pit was dug in a sheltered place where it wasn't windy right now, but 50 meters higher, the wind was stronger, and it was loading snow and making windslab.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit is adjacent to avalanche: other;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit was dug adjacent to skier-triggered avalanche on same aspect. Pit also dug on scree field and had slightly variable depths.

Profile dug at treeline in a sparsely treed area. Assessing the basal layer and reactivity of weak layers with the new load. Dec1 SH layer was not identified, compression test failing below Dec5-6 complex at 37cm may have been on this layer.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; We snowmobiled slope;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Cold temps, calm winds that picked up to Light from the west at 10,900'. Structure at this location on a SW aspect was dry faceted snow. Granted this is only one data point- but similar to west facing. Without more of a slab (wind or new snow); stability tests show it isn't going to avalanche. GCS
lee side

amateur snow pit.
The failure at 15cm depth did not break in the test, but I was able to clean shear it off after the failure on the basal DH layer. It is unclear if that layer is near surface facets or surface hoar. I could not find any surface hour under loupe.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Smá flekamyndun efst, brotnar efst í nýsnævis laginu á um 20 cm dýpi. Örlítið stafara ofaná. Gætu orsakað lítil flekaflóð. Köntun ofarlega í skaralaginu sem kom brot á í einu prófi en virðist ekki útbreitt, mjög breytilegt í gryfju og ólíklegt að þetta sé vandamál.
